intro: Oryza sativa var. caspica, commonly known as the Caspian rice, is a botanical variety of rice native to the Caspian Sea region. It is characterized by its short, plump grains and high amylose content, which contributes to its firm texture when cooked. This variety thrives in temperate climates with well-drained soils and requires a moderate amount of water during its growth cycle. It is often cultivated for its nutritional value and adaptability to specific environmental conditions. The plant typically grows to a height of 100–150 cm, with erect stems and panicles that bear small, white flowers.
